Models

Source: vignettes/Models.Rmd
Models.Rmd

Suppose we have total nn subjects from mm transplant centers with nin_i records from center ii (i=1,...,mi = 1, ..., m). Coefficients of risk factors are denoted by ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} = (Î²1,â€¦,Î²P)T(\beta_1, \dots, \beta_P)^T, and let ğ›„=(Î³1,...,Î³m)T\boldsymbol{\gamma} = (\gamma_1, ..., \gamma_m)^T denote the effect of centers.

Generalized Linear Models

Let YijY_{ij} denotes the outcome variable for record j(j=1,...,nij \ (j = 1, ..., n_i) of center ii, and let ğ—ij\boldsymbol{X}_{ij} be the corresponding 1Ã—P1 \times P vector of risk factors. We assume that given the linear predictor Î·ij:=Î³i+ğ—ijğ›ƒ\eta_{ij} := \gamma_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}, the outcome YijY_{ij} follows a distribution in the exponential family. Incorporate with penalty terms, our problem of interest is estimating ğ›‰=(ğ›„T,ğ›ƒT)T\boldsymbol{\theta} = (\boldsymbol{\gamma}^T, \boldsymbol{\beta}^T)^T by minimizing:

QÎ»(ğ›‰)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Yij(Î³i+ğ—ijğ›ƒ)âˆ’b(Î³i+ğ—ijğ›ƒ)}+âˆ‘p=1PÎ»p|Î²p|,Q_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = -\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij}(\gamma_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta}) - b(\gamma_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij}\boldsymbol{\beta})\} + \sum_{p = 1}^P \lambda_{p} |\beta_p|, where Î»p\lambda_{p}(p=1,2,...,P)(p = 1,2,...,P) is the regularization parameter for Î²p\beta_p.

Two-layer iterative update procedure

outer layer: update the provider effect ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma}

Given the previous iterationâ€™s estimate of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} (denoted as ğ›ƒÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}), consider QÎ»,ğ›„(ğ›„)âˆQÎ»((ğ›„T,ğ›ƒÌƒT)T)Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\gamma}}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) \propto Q_{\lambda}((\boldsymbol{\gamma}^T, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^T)^T) that is defined as QÎ»,ğ›„(ğ›„)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Yij(Î³i+ğ—ijğ›ƒÌƒ)âˆ’b(Î³i+ğ—ijğ›ƒÌƒ)}. Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\gamma}}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij}(\gamma_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) - b(\gamma_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})\}.

Since the score function of QÎ»,ğ›„(ğ›„)Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\gamma}}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) is separable for ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma} and the fisher information matrix is diagonal, Î³i\gamma_i can be updated separately using only a subset of the entire data by a one-step Newton procedure:

Î³Ì‚i=Î³iÌƒ+IÎ»âˆ’1(Î³Ìƒi)UÎ»(Î³Ìƒi).\hat{\gamma}_i = \tilde{\gamma_i} + I_{\lambda}^{-1}(\tilde{\gamma}_i) U_{\lambda}(\tilde{\gamma}_i).

inner layer: update the covariate coefficient ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}

Based on the updated value of ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma} (i.e.Â the ğ›„Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}} that was updated previously), consider QÎ»,ğ›ƒ(ğ›ƒ)=QÎ»((ğ›„Ì‚T,ğ›ƒT)T)=1nâ„’Î²(ğ›ƒ)+âˆ‘p=1PÎ»p|Î²p|,Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\beta}}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) = Q_{\lambda}((\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}^T, \boldsymbol{\beta}^T)^T) = \frac{1}{n}\mathcal{L}_{\beta}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) + \sum_{p = 1}^P \lambda_{p} |\beta_p|, where â„’Î²(ğ›ƒ)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Yij(Î³Ì‚i+ğ—ijğ›ƒ)âˆ’b(Î³Ì‚i+ğ—ijğ›ƒ)}\mathcal{L}_{\beta}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) = - \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij}(\hat{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}) - b(\hat{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta})\}.

The coordinate-wise updating function of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} utilizing the sub-differential calculus is given by: Î²Ì‚p=S{âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niwÌƒijXijp(Z(Î·Ìƒij)âˆ’Î³Ì‚iâˆ’ğ—ijğ›ƒÌ‚(âˆ’p)),nÎ»p}âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niwÌƒijXijp2,\hat{\beta}_p = \frac{S\{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \tilde{w}_{ij} {X_{ijp}} (Z(\tilde{\eta}_{ij}) - \hat{\gamma}_i - \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{(-p)}), n\lambda_p\}}{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \tilde{w}_{ij} {X_{ijp}}^2}, where S(Z,Î»)={Zâˆ’Î»,ifZ>Î»0,ifâˆ’Î»â‰¤Zâ‰¤Î»Z+Î»,ifZ<âˆ’Î»,S(Z, \lambda) = \begin{cases} Z - \lambda,\ \ \text{if} \ \ \ Z > \lambda \\ \ \ \ 0, \ \ \ \ \ \text{if} \ -\lambda \leq Z \leq \lambda \\ Z + \lambda, \ \ \text{if} \ \ \ Z < -\lambda \end{cases},Z(Î·Ìƒij)=Î³Ì‚i+ğ—ijğ›ƒÌƒâˆ’{â„’Î·â€³(ğ›ˆÌƒ)âˆ’1â„’Î·â€²(ğ›ˆÌƒ)}ij,Z(\tilde{\eta}_{ij}) = \hat{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{X}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} - \{\mathcal{L}_{\eta}''(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}) ^{-1} \mathcal{L}_{\eta}'(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}})\}_{ij}, and Ï‰Ìƒij=â„’Î·â€³(ğ›ˆÌƒ)ij.\tilde{\omega}_{ij} = \mathcal{L}_{\eta}''(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}})_{ij}.

Extensions: Covariates with Group Information

Let ğ—ij\boldsymbol{X}_{ij} be a 1Ã—âˆ‘k=1Kpk1 \times \sum_{k = 1}^K p_k vector of risk factors that are divided into KK non-overlapping groups (pkp_k denotes the length of group kk). The coefficients of risk factors are denoted by ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} = (ğ›ƒ1T(\boldsymbol{\beta}_1^T, â€¦, ğ›ƒKT)T\boldsymbol{\beta}_K^T)^T. Given the observed data {(Yij,ğ—ij)}\{(Y_{ij}, \boldsymbol{X}_{ij})\}, our problem of interest becomes estimating ğ›‰=(ğ›„T,ğ›ƒT)T\boldsymbol{\theta} = (\boldsymbol{\gamma}^T, \boldsymbol{\beta}^T)^T by minimizing QÎ»(ğ›‰)=1nâ„’(ğ›‰)+âˆ‘k=1KÎ»k||ğ›ƒk||2, Q_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \frac{1}{n} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) + \sum_{k = 1}^K \lambda_k ||\boldsymbol{\beta}_k||_2, where â„’(ğ›‰)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni{Yij(Î³i+âˆ‘k=1Kğ—ijkğ›ƒk)âˆ’b(Î³i+âˆ‘k=1Kğ—ijkğ›ƒk)}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = - \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \{Y_{ij}(\gamma_i + \sum_{k = 1}^K \boldsymbol{X}_{ijk}\boldsymbol{\beta}_k) - b(\gamma_i + \sum_{k = 1}^K \boldsymbol{X}_{ijk}\boldsymbol{\beta}_k)\} is the loss function, and ||ğ›ƒk||2||\boldsymbol{\beta}_k||_2 is the L2L_2 norm of ğ›ƒk\boldsymbol{\beta}_k. Î»k\lambda_k is the regularization parameter on group kk with default Î»k=Î»pk\lambda_k = \lambda \sqrt{p_k}.

In the outer layer of each iteration, the center effects ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma}â€™s are updated the same way as we discussed previously.

In the inner layer, we use the Majorize-Minimization (MM) algorithm to improve the efficiency of our algorithm for binary outcomes. Based on the current value of ğ›„Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}, the subdifferential-based group-wise updating function of the objective function is given by ğ›ƒk={(||ğ³Ìƒk||âˆ’Î»kv)ğ³Ìƒk||ğ³Ìƒk||,ifvâ‹…||ğ³Ìƒk||>Î»k0,ifvâ‹…||ğ³Ìƒk||â‰¤Î»k,\boldsymbol{\beta}_k = \begin{cases} (||\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k|| - \frac{\lambda_k}{v}) \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k}{||\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k||}, & \text{if} \ \ v\cdot||\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k|| > \lambda_k \\ 0, & \text{if} \ \ v\cdot||\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k|| \leq \lambda_k \end{cases}, where ğ³Ìƒk=1nğ—kT(Z(ğ›ˆÌƒ)âˆ’ğ›„Ì‚âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ(âˆ’k))\tilde{\boldsymbol{z}}_k = \frac{1}{n} {\boldsymbol{X}_k}^T (Z(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}) - \hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}} - \boldsymbol{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{(-k)}) and v=0.25v = 0.25. ğ›ƒÌƒ(âˆ’k)\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{(-k)} is the most recently updated value of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} but set ğ›ƒÌƒk\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_k to ğŸ\boldsymbol{0}, Z(ğ›ˆÌƒ)=ğ˜Z(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}) = \boldsymbol{Y} for continuous outcome and Z(ğ›ˆÌƒ)=ğ›„Ì‚+ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ+1v(ğ˜âˆ’ğ©Ìƒ)Z(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}) = \hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}} + \boldsymbol{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} + \frac{1}{v}(\boldsymbol{Y} - \tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}) for binary outcome.

Discrete Survival Logistic Model

Let TÌƒij\tilde{T}_{ij} represent the underlying uncensored failure time and CijC_{ij} be the censoring time of individual jj of center ii. Let ğ™ij\boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} denote the 1Ã—p1 \times p vector of risk factors of jthj^{th} individual from center ii, Î”i\Delta_i is the center indicator, and TijT_{ij} be the corresponding observed failure or censor time with â‹ƒ{Tij}={t1,t2,...,tK}\bigcup\{T_{ij}\} = \{t_{1}, t_{2}, ..., t_{K}\}, where t1<t2<â‹¯<tKt_{1} < t_{2} < \cdots < t_{K} is the discrete failure times indexed by m=1,2,...,Km = 1, 2, ..., K. We assume that TÌƒij\tilde{T}_{ij} is independent with CijC_{ij} given ğ™ij\boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} and Î”i\Delta_i. Let Î»(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i)=P(TÌƒij=ti|TÌƒijâ‰¥tk,ğ™ij,Î”i)\lambda(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i) = P(\tilde{T}_{ij} = t_i | \tilde{T}_{ij} \geq t_k, \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i) be the hazard for the individual with risk factor ğ™ij\boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} and from center ii at time tkt_k, and let ğ’Ÿi,k\mathcal{D}_{i,k} and ğ’i,k\mathcal{C}_{i,k} be the set of indices attached to individuals from center ii failing and censoring at tkt_k, respectively.

The full likelihood function is given by

L=âˆk=1Kâˆi=1m{âˆjâˆˆğ’Ÿi,k[F(tkâˆ’;ğ™ij,Î”i)âˆ’F(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i)]âˆjâˆˆğ’i,kF(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i)}, L=\prod_{k=1}^{K} \prod_{i=1}^{m} \left\{\prod_{j \in \mathcal{D}_{i,k}} [F(t_k^-; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i) - F(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i)] \prod_{j \in \mathcal{C}_{i,k}} F(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i)\right\}, where F(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i)=P(TÌƒij>tk|ğ™ij,Î”i)=âˆlâˆ£tlâ‰¤tk{1âˆ’Î»(tl;ğ™ij,Î”i)}F(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i) = P(\tilde{T}_{ij} > t_k|\boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i) = \prod\limits_{l \mid t_{l} \leq t_k}\{1 - \lambda(t_l; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i)\} is the survival function at time tkt_k corresponding to individual from center ii with covariate ğ™ij\boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}. Let Î»0(tk)\lambda_0(t_k) be the discrete baseline hazard function at time tkt_k, then the hazard relationship for the discrete-time logistic model is defined as:

log(Î»(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i)1âˆ’Î»(tk;ğ™ij,Î”i))=log(Î»0(tk)1âˆ’Î»0(tk))+Î³i+ğ™ijğ›ƒ.log(\frac{\lambda(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i)}{1 - \lambda(t_k; \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij}, \Delta_i)}) = log(\frac{\lambda_0(t_k)}{1 - \lambda_0(t_k)}) + \gamma_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}. Let Î±k=log(Î»0(tk)1âˆ’Î»0(tk))\alpha_k = log(\frac{\lambda_0(t_k)}{1 - \lambda_0(t_k)}), then our problem of interest is estimating ğ›‰=(ğ›‚ğ“,ğ›„T,ğ›ƒT)T\boldsymbol{\theta} = (\boldsymbol{\boldsymbol{\alpha}^T, \gamma}^T, \boldsymbol{\beta}^T)^T by minimizing:

QÎ»(ğ›‰)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niâˆ‘k=1kij{Î´ij(tk)â‹…(Î±k+Î³i+ğ™ijğ›ƒ)âˆ’log(1+eÎ±k+Î³i+ğ™ijğ›ƒ)}+âˆ‘p=1PÎ»p|Î²p|Q_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = -\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \sum_{k=1}^{k_{ij}} \{\delta_{ij}\left(t_{k}\right) \cdot (\alpha_k + \gamma_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}) -log(1 + e^{\alpha_k + \gamma_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}}) \} + \sum_{p = 1}^P \lambda_{p} |\beta_p|

Three-layer iterative update procedure

outer layer: update the log-transformed baseline hazard ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha}

Given the previous iterationâ€™s estimate of center effect ğ›„Ìƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\gamma}} and coefficient of risk factors ğ›ƒÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, we consider QÎ»,ğ›‚(ğ›‚)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niâˆ‘k=1kij{Î´ij(tk)â‹…(Î±k+Î³Ìƒi+ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ)âˆ’log(1+eÎ±k+Î³Ìƒi+ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ)}Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_i} \sum\limits_{k=1}^{k_{ij}} \{\delta_{ij}\left(t_{k}\right) \cdot (\alpha_k + \tilde{\gamma}_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) -log(1 + e^{\alpha_k + \tilde{\gamma}_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}) \}. The Newton method allows us to update ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma} separately by: Î±Ì‚k=Î±Ìƒk+IÎ»âˆ’1(Î±Ìƒk)UÎ»(Î±Ìƒk),\hat{\alpha}_k = \tilde{\alpha}_k + I_{\lambda}^{-1}(\tilde{\alpha}_k) U_{\lambda}(\tilde{\alpha}_k), where Î±Ìƒk\tilde{\alpha}_k is the current value of Î±k\alpha_k, and $$U_{\lambda}(\tilde{\alpha}_k) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^m \{\sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \delta_{ij} \left(t_{k}\right) - \sum_{j|T_{ij} \geq t_k} \frac{e^{\tilde{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{\tilde{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}\} \\ I_{\lambda}(\tilde{\alpha}_k) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^m \sum_{j|T_{ij} \geq t_k} \frac{e^{\tilde{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{(1 + e^{\tilde{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}})^2}.$$

middle layer: update the provider effect ğ›„\boldsymbol{\gamma}

Given the ğ›‚Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\alpha}} updated above and the most recently updated ğ›ƒÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, we consider QÎ»,ğ›„(ğ›„)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niâˆ‘k=1kij{Î´ij(tk)â‹…(Î±Ì‚k+Î³i+ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ)âˆ’log(1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î³i+ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ)}Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\gamma}}(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_i} \sum\limits_{k=1}^{k_{ij}} \{\delta_{ij}\left(t_{k}\right) \cdot (\hat{\alpha}_k + \gamma_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) -log(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \gamma_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}) \}. Use a similar one-step Newton method we should have Î³Ì‚i=Î³Ìƒi+IÎ»âˆ’1(Î³Ìƒi)UÎ»(Î³Ìƒi),\hat{\gamma}_i = \tilde{\gamma}_i + I_{\lambda}^{-1}(\tilde{\gamma}_i) U_{\lambda}(\tilde{\gamma}_i), where Î³i\gamma_{i} represent the most recently updated value of effect of center ii, and $$U_{\lambda}(\tilde{\gamma}_i) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \sum_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}} \{\delta_{ij} \left(t_{k}\right) - \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}\} \\ I_{\lambda}(\tilde{\gamma}_i) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j = 1}^{n_i} \sum_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}} \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}}{(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\gamma}_i + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}})^2}.$$

It should be noted that the effect of the first provider is set to zero (as the reference group) to prevent issues of multicollinearity.

inner layer: update the covariate coefficient ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}

Based on the ğ›‚Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\alpha}} and ğ›„Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}} updated from the previous two steps, define â„’Î²(ğ›ƒ)=âˆ’1nâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niâˆ‘k=1kij{Î´ij(tk)â‹…(Î±Ì‚k+Î³Ì‚i+ğ™ijğ›ƒ)âˆ’log(1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î³Ì‚i+ğ™ijğ›ƒ)}\mathcal{L}_{\beta}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) = - \frac{1}{n} \sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_i} \sum\limits_{k=1}^{k_{ij}} \{\delta_{ij}\left(t_{k}\right) \cdot (\hat{\alpha}_k + \hat{\gamma}_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}) -log(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \hat{\gamma}_{i} + \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \boldsymbol{\beta}}) \} and consider QÎ»,ğ›ƒ(ğ›ƒ)=1nâ„’Î²(ğ›ƒ)+âˆ‘k=1pÎ»k|Î²k|.Q_{\lambda, \boldsymbol{\beta}}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \frac{1}{n} \mathcal{L}_{\beta}(\boldsymbol{\beta}) + \sum_{k = 1}^p \lambda_{k} |\beta_k|.

Denote Z(Î·Ìƒij)=Î·Ìƒijâˆ’{â„’Î·â€³(ğ›ˆÌƒ)âˆ’1â„’Î·â€²(ğ›ˆÌƒ)}ij=Î·Ìƒij+âˆ‘k=1kij[Î´ij(tk)âˆ’eÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij]âˆ‘k=1kijeÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij(1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij)2,Z(\tilde{\eta}_{ij}) = \tilde{\eta}_{ij} - \{\mathcal{L}_{\eta}''(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}})^{-1} \mathcal{L}_{\eta}'(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}})\}_{ij} = \tilde{\eta}_{ij} + \frac{\sum\limits_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}}[\delta_{ij}(t_k) - \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}}}{1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}}}]}{\sum\limits_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}} \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}}}{(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}})^2}}, and Ï‰Ìƒij=âˆ‘k=1kijeÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij(1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î·Ìƒij)2,\tilde{\omega}_{ij} = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}} \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}}}{(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_k + \tilde{\eta}_{ij}})^2}, then the coordinate-wise updating function will be given by: Î²p=S{âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niwÌƒijZijp(Z(Î·Ìƒij)âˆ’Î³Ì‚iâˆ’ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ(âˆ’p)),nÎ»k}âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niwÌƒijZijp2,\beta_p = \frac{S\{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \tilde{w}_{ij} {Z_{ijp}} (Z(\tilde{\eta}_{ij}) - \hat{\gamma}_i - \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{(-p)}), n\lambda_k\}}{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} \tilde{w}_{ij} {Z_{ijp}}^2}, where SS is the same soft-thresholding operator defined above.

MM algorithm can also be applied for solving this problem since âˆ‘k=1kijeÎ±Ì‚k+Î·ij(1+eÎ±Ì‚k+Î·ij)2<14kij\sum\limits_{k = 1}^{k_{ij}} \frac{e^{\hat{\alpha}_{k} + \eta_{ij}}}{(1 + e^{\hat{\alpha}_{k} + \eta_{ij}})^2} < \frac{1}{4} k_{ij}. The majorizing surrogate function is constructed based on ğ–=(14k11â‹±14km,nm)nÃ—n,\boldsymbol{W} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{4}k_{11} & & \\ & \ddots & \\ & & \frac{1}{4}k_{m,n_m} \end{pmatrix}_{n \times n}, and the corresponding updating function is given by Î²p=S{âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nikijZijp(Z(Î·Ìƒij)âˆ’Î³Ì‚iâˆ’ğ™ijğ›ƒÌƒ(âˆ’p)),4nÎ»k}âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1nikijZijp2.\beta_p = \frac{S\{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} k_{ij} {Z_{ijp}} (Z(\tilde{\eta}_{ij}) - \hat{\gamma}_i - \boldsymbol{Z}_{ij} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{(-p)}), 4n\lambda_k\}}{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^m \sum\limits_{j = 1}^{n_i} k_{ij} {Z_{ijp}}^2}.
